commit_message:
Add extra DHCP routes

Previously DHCP extra routes (subnet host_routes) were not
implemented by networking_calico. Now we will populate the host
routes in etcd and implement them in the Calico DHCP agent.

Closes-Bug: #1602313
Change-Id: Iafaadef7bb6f740d3018b6107f3c9990ca02e16b

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-06 10:25:58.000000000', 'files': ['muranoclient/common/utils.py', 'releasenotes/notes/multi-class-yamls-support-914b3d155324214f.yaml', 'muranoclient/v1/artifact_packages.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient/commit/56605d2740a4088631117cd44276f2b13c2a2a07', 'message': 'Support for multi-class yamls in client

MuranoClient needs to analyse package classes (names and inheritance
chains) to properly add packages to Glare. This requires it to
properly resolve class names in the appropriate namespaces.

Since Mitaka Murano supports multi-class yamls, i.e. yaml files
containing multiple MuranoPL classes in a single yaml file using it
multi-document format. Optionally this allows to reuse a single
namespace definition for multiple classes defined in the same file.

Client was not aware of this feature, always loading classes as
single-document yamls. It was also always using the current-class
namespace definitions, thus likely to fail if the shared namespace
definition is in use.

This has been addressed.

Closes-bug: #1608440
Change-Id: Ibd08454f71e0266c76a2ac517b441df97311d8b9
(cherry picked from commit 98adda6a46fd5d2032077758de1d72cefe4ef55c)
'}]
commit_message:
Support for multi-class yamls in client

MuranoClient needs to analyse package classes (names and inheritance
chains) to properly add packages to Glare. This requires it to
properly resolve class names in the appropriate namespaces.

Since Mitaka Murano supports multi-class yamls, i.e. yaml files
containing multiple MuranoPL classes in a single yaml file using it
multi-document format. Optionally this allows to reuse a single
namespace definition for multiple classes defined in the same file.

Client was not aware of this feature, always loading classes as
single-document yamls. It was also always using the current-class
namespace definitions, thus likely to fail if the shared namespace
definition is in use.

This has been addressed.

Closes-bug: #1608440
Change-Id: Ibd08454f71e0266c76a2ac517b441df97311d8b9
(cherry picked from commit 98adda6a46fd5d2032077758de1d72cefe4ef55c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/15/352015/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Fixed a bug when a package containing multi-class yamls could not be added to glare-based catalog.

commit_message:
Added better error messages during (un)pinning CPUs

Error messages during pinning and unpinning are same.
It's a confusing especially during migration for example.
You got message like "Cannot pin/unpin cpus [17] from the
following pinned set [3]" and you can't understand is it
a problem with removing a VM from old compute node
or with booting a VM on new compute node.

We should split these two cases.

Change-Id: Ic70ecdfa414fd8558d453fbf1c21640c8acc3ea1

commit_message:
[WIP] Proposes exposing additional api filter options for collections based on db node attributes.

Change-Id: I4f7be7708c70bbed8cc850ced47f5c3094e9cf2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/12/229512/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Expose all filter options for collections in REST api ================================================== Included launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/expose-collection-filters This is intended to enable capabilities of getting ironic node data out of the db via REST and filtering which would otherwise need to be done by manually filtering. Why are we doing anything? The intention is to allow for api filtering access of collection data that would otherwise be left for the end user to process client side. Any field the sqlalchemy models define should allow for filtering and this would promote using the ironic api or client for queries over connecting directly to the database. Looking for feedback at this point and can further add to this spec if deemed viable. Problem description =================== In the ironic.api.v1.node.Node._get_nodes_collection method there are hardcoded filters based on default arguments passed in. These filters do not expose all of the available fields on the sqlalchemy db model for nodes and can make the end user or admin user filter by whats available and then client side filter beyond that. That is to say if they don't decide to access the database manually to get the needed info. Proposed change =============== Adding **filters to ironic.api.v1.node.Node._get_nodes_collection would allow us to pass in any filters we would like. This can be validated using the node fields property to ensure the filter key is valid. Depending on the implementation, we could also pass in an operator for better filter evaluation. This would also involve refactoring ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.Connection._add_nodes_filters to not be hardcoded and better handle the evaluations. Retaining the existing evaluations can be done by setting defaults on this method or similar. Essentially, enabling access to each of the fields defined in ironic.objects.node.Node.fields to be used as filter criteria when querying the ironic rest api for node collections. This should also validate the type based on the field definition in ironic.db.sqlalchemy.models.Node to ensure compatbile filter requests. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: naterh <nhouse@gmail.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== This should retain backwards compatibility as its leaving the method signatures intact with the addition of **filters Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Added IPA ssl/client certificate spec

Change-Id: Ie09b720aa62b8a2fcd143bfaf3a1fe0137e385de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/82/112682/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================= Add SSL to the IPA API, Including Client Certificate Checking ============================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ipa-ssl-and-client-certs This specification proposes the addition of SSL (HTTPS) support to the Ironic Python Agent (IPA) API, including optional client certificate verification for authentication purposes. Additionally, it proposes changes to Ironic needed to connect to IPA via SSL, optionally using a client certificate. Problem description =================== Currently, the Ironic Python Agent API uses no authentication whatsoever, exposing an HTTP API that anyone can use, potentially for malicious purposes. As a first step, this API should support SSL (HTTPS), and the use of client certificates to authenticate requests. Proposed change =============== * Modify IPA to support SSL, and advertise an https:// address if so configured * Modify IPA to check client certificates against a configured set of certificate authorities. * Modify the Ironic Conductor to connect via SSL to those IPAs that advertise an https:// address, and use a client certificate if so configured. Alternatives ------------ Data model impact ----------------- REST API impact --------------- Driver API impact ----------------- Nova driver impact ------------------ Security impact --------------- Other end user impact --------------------- Scalability impact ------------------ Performance Impact ------------------ Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ==========

commit_message:
Add indexable JSON fields spec

This spec presents the work needed to make some JSON fields from the
Ironic node resource indexable in the database so they can be filtered
in a performant way.

Change-Id: I1c21262eb5f45696c8308977ae5af970e34c5365
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/05/253605/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================== Indexable JSON fields ===================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/indexable-json-fields This spec presents the work needed to make some JSON fields from the Ironic node resource indexable in the database so they can be filtered in a performant way. Problem description =================== Ironic currently store some data as JSON in the database, this was done by design and have served us well until recently where a consensus decision was made for having a way to filter data stored into some of these fields via the Ironic API. In order to be able to filter resources in a performant way Ironic needs the data of those JSON fields to be indexable. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes separating the node's ``properties`` and ``driver_info`` JSON fields into separated database tables. Both fields contains information that would come handy if able to filter to use for scheduling and inspecting purpose. Since many nodes are likely to have the same field names for ``properties`` (e.g cpus, memory, disk etc...) and ``driver_info`` (e.g credentials, deploy kernel, deploy ramdisk etc...) this spec propose creating separate tables for ``properties`` and ``driver_info`` names and cross-join tables between nodes and the new tables. The database tables layout are: **properties**: (id INT PRIMARY KEY, field_name VARCHAR(255), UNIQUE(field_name)) **node_properties** (node_id INT, property_id INT, FOREIGN KEY (node_id, property_id), PRIMARY KEY (node_id, property_id), INDEX (property_id), field_value JSON) **driver_info** (id INT PRIMARY KEY, field_name VARCHAR(255), UNIQUE(field_name)) **node_driver_info** (node_id INT, driver_info_id INT, FOREIGN KEY (node_id, driver_info_id), PRIMARY KEY (node_id, driver_info_id), INDEX (driver_info_id), field_value JSON) This spec also will implement migration scripts to move the data from those fields into the new tables. Alternatives ------------ None. Indexing the fields in the database is performatic but it would be possible to do the filtering (whether in Ironic or on the client side) by loading all nodes and introspecting the JSON blobs. Although this is very inefficient. Data model impact ----------------- Four new tables will be added: ``properties``, ``node_properties``, ``driver_info`` and ``node_driver_info``. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None. The work described in this spec is just plumbing work, once in place new features can be implemented on top of it that will impact on the performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: lucasagomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create the ``properties``, ``node_properties``, ``driver_info`` and ``node_driver_info`` tables. * Create a migration script to move the data from the node's ``properties`` and ``driver_info`` columns into their respective tables. * Drop the ``properties`` and ``driver_info`` column from the ``nodes`` table. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unittests will be added for the new code and migration scripts. All the other tests should work as before. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== * Migration scripts will be provided to create the new tables and move the data around. Documentation Impact ==================== None. Since this is only plumbing work there's no impact on the users of Ironic whatsoever, things should just work as is. References ========== None

commit_message:
Add spec for pluggable distributed synchronization

Implements: blueprint pluggable-distributed-synchronization

Change-Id: If83944fe3021922ec2a94c67f3ef57a8f7461905
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/32/114632/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Pluggable Distributed Synchronization ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/pluggable-distributed-synchronization Today Ironic does database-backed locking for distributed synchronization. For example, there is a column in the node table, which a process can put its hostname in to "lock" the node so that other processes won't modify the data. If one doesn't trust database locking (deadlocks if a conductor dies), there are currently no alternatives, nor a way to implement/use alternative backends. Problem description =================== There is currently no clean way to implement other distributed synchronization backends for locking. Proposed change =============== * Creation of `ironic.sync` module containing a common `BaseSyncManager` interface that can used to implement backends for distributed synchronization. * A single implementation of database-backed locking will be included. This will be a refactor (extraction) of the current acquire/release dbapi backed locking currently found in `TaskManager`. * Update `TaskManager` to use the `sync` module for node locking operations. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- * A `backend` config option under `sync` used to specify the backend for locking. * Default: `dbapi` Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kylestev Work Items ---------- TODO 1. Creation of `ironic.sync` module containing a common `BaseSyncManager` interface that can used to implement backends for distributed synchronization. 2. Implement database API backed SyncManager as default and update `TaskManager` to use the `ironic.sync` module for acquiring/releasing locks Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= * Unit tests should suffice. * Does not expose any public interfaces for Tempest to test. Documentation Impact ==================== * Pluggable synchronization config documentation References ========== None.

commit_message:
Chassis Level Discovery Tool

Change-Id: Id9fc8ee87ca3e6c75494d187bf8f1e9495b5cec6
Implements: Blueprint chassis-level-node-discovery
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/66/134866/28 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Chassis level Discovery of Nodes ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/chassis-level-node-discovery This blueprint proposes to enable Discovery of Nodes and associated properties at Ironic Chassis level. Problem description =================== Ironic maintains its own database to register bare metal nodes and store their properties such as mac address, cores, cpu arch etc Currently, this registration should be done manually by firing individual ironic node-create command for each node. It becomes cumbersome when there are too many nodes to be registered and managed by the cloud. For example, in the case of moonshot hardware, an enclosure can have 45 to 180 nodes and registering all these by issuing a separate command is very time-consuming and difficult. Ironic can be customized to initiate discovery and registration of hardware details using a single command. Proposed change =============== Ironic has a logical entity, Chassis, to group the bare metal nodes based on their enclosures. For certain hardware such as moonshot, Chassis is a physical entity in which the cartridges and nodes are present. For such hardware, the logical grouping in Ironic can be made use to actually represent the physical chassis. In others, it can still remain a logical grouping. Ironic command for Chassis creation can be enhanced by providing fields to enter the location and credentials of the hardware. This will in turn trigger discovery of the nodes associated with the chassis through a hardware specific discovery driver. The chassis-create command of ironic altered to include the following options: # ironic chassis-create --description xxxxx --discovery_driver xxxx --driver_info host=xxxx --driver_info username=xxxx --driver_info password=xxxx Discovery mechanism is specific to the hardware. Out-Of-Band and In-Band are two ways to discover nodes in a chassis. Using the technique suitable to the hardware, a discovery driver can be written. For example, for moonshot hardware, discovery is done out-of-band using the RIS interface of the Chassis Manager Console. The driver-info parameter is used to supply the driver details to reach the Chassis and discover the nodes. The above command does the following: -> Creates a Chassis -> Discovers Node properties and switch port details -> Registers the Node details in the database and associates them to the Chassis -> Registers Port information. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- This will add two fields - `discovery_driver` and 'driver_info' to the Chassis table. These fields will default to NULL, which will also be the value when discovery is not triggered REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- When a chassis which mandates node discovery process is registered, provide the appropriate parameteres: * --discovery_driver * --driver_info host=<VALUE> * --driver_info username=<VALUE> * --driver_info password=<VALUE> Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sandhya-ganapathy Other contributors: bmahalakshmi Work Items ---------- * When a chassis being registered has discovery details specified, trigger discovery of the nodes belonging to the chassis. * Changes to the chassis addition mechanism to parse the credentials provided. * Addition of a discovery driver template that can be extended for writing vendor specific discovery mechanism Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit test cases to test Node discovery while registering a chassis with hardware access details. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation should reflect the parameters that can be provided while registering a chassis to tigger discovery process. References ========== None.

commit_message:
exposing driver capabilities

This spec proposes to expose the capabilities
for a driver. This proposes to add new end points.

Change-Id: Id5607b7d4da4963c39ae54499e1719054a5c0db4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/01/182601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Introduce Driver Capabilities ========================================== This spec introduces inspectable (via Ironic API) capabilities for Ironic drivers. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/driver-capabilities Problem description =================== Capabilities are required for at least these use cases: * Scheduling on a node with a proper driver. E.g. with time we start implementing variants of deployment that are not supported by all drivers, including: * Whole-disk vs partition deployment [1]. * Using configdrive for deployment [2]. * Using ephemeral partitions. We need to take all these differences into account when scheduling. Failure to do so will lead to errors on the late stage of deployment or even (as with whole-disk) to the wrong deployment. Ironic should be able to aggregate driver capabilities into node capabilities to expose them to the scheduler. (Not addressed by this spec.) * Examining driver features. As we are introducing more vendor-specific things, we need some way to find out, if one is supported by a given driver. Driver capabilities would enable 3rd-party tools to inspect support of particular feature by particular driver. Proposed change =============== * Introduce get_capabilities() call to all driver interfaces, return value being set of strings. * Introduce get_capabilities() call to ``BaseDriver``, defaulting to union of capabilities of all interfaces. * Publish capabilities as ``/v1/drivers/{name}/capabilities`` REST endpoint. With the above changes, a developer could use the Ironic API to go through the list of drivers and inspect their capabilities. Alternatives ------------ * Obviously the best solution would be to have all drivers implement the same set of capabilities. Unfortunately, it's not realistic. E.g. some drivers (like IPMI) are more generic than the other (like ILO and DRAC), but we don't want to artificialy limit what more specific drivers can expose. Data model impact ----------------- None. For now we expect driver capabilities to be a hardcoded constant. REST API impact --------------- * ``/v1/drivers/{name}/capabilities`` * Get driver capabilities. * Method type GET. * Normal http response code(s): 200 * Expected error http response code(s) * 404 - driver not found. * Parameter: ``name`` - driver name * Body: None * Response: JSON list of strings. * A corresponding change in the client library and CLI is necessary, e.g. :: $ ironic driver-get-capabilities pxe_ipmitool RPC API impact -------------- * New synchronous RPC method ``get_driver_capabilities``, taking ``driver_name``, returning list of capabilities. Driver API impact ----------------- * New method ``get_capabilities`` added to all interfaces, defaulting to returning an empty set. * New method ``get_capabilities`` added to the ``BaseDriver``, defaulting to returning a union of ``get_capabilities`` results for all interfaces. Change is backward-compatible. Nova driver impact ------------------ None for now. This spec is a starting point to implement hardware capabilities for nodes [3], which will affect Nova driver. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- * New CLI command: ``ironic driver-get-capabilities <driver name>`` Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- * Driver developers can override ``get_capabilities`` to provide information about additional capabilities. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Work Items ---------- * Add ``get_capabilities`` to all interfaces. * Add ``get_capabilities`` to the ``BaseDriver``. * Add ``get_driver_capabilities`` to the RPC API. * Add new REST API. * Research whether to add capabilities to existing drivers. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== No upgrade impact Documentation Impact ==================== * New API should be documented. * Driver documentation should mention the new method. References ========== * [1] https://review.openstack.org/97150 * [2] https://review.openstack.org/99235 * [3] https://review.openstack.org/131272

commit_message:
Add ZooKeeper SyncManager spec to Kilo specs

Implements: blueprint zookeeper-syncmanager

Change-Id: Ie44f68960d5a1aad5a8b2b967f2deeada3d50832
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/40/117040/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== ZooKeeper SyncManager ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/zookeeper-syncmanager Today Ironic does database-backed locking for various things. Currently, there is a column in the node table, which a process can put its hostname in to "lock" the node so that other processes will not attempt to mess with the data. While this works, it is vulnerable to deadlock scenarios when a conductor is partitioned or dies, which can lead to nodes being locked in the database until a third party (be it human or script) intervenes and removes the lock. Apache ZooKeeper has built in mechanisms that allow for implementation of a safer locking mechanism that releases locks upon client disconnect. The purpose of this spec is to implement ZooKeeper backed locking. An implementation of `Pluggable Distributed Synchronization`_ [1]. Problem description =================== 1. If the process dies before it unlocks the node, that node will remain permanently locked unless there is human intervention. 2. There is no way to easily wait for a lock to be released besides polling the row in the database periodically (currently every 1000ms). Proposed change =============== Implement a `ZookeeperSyncManager` class that will facilitate node locking and unlocking. Alternatives ------------ The `StackForge Tooz`_ [2] project has ZooKeeper locking in it, and it also provides pluggable locking with other backends. Including it into this spec might turn the `Pluggable Distributed Synchronization`_ [1] spec into pluggable-pluggable-locking. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- * Operators who choose to use the ZooKeeper plugin will need to point the config at a `ZooKeeper Ensemble`_ [4]. While ZooKeeper does have ACL functionality built in, I do not believe it is needed for this spec. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ * Additional network calls to internal ZooKeeper endpoints. * Additional network traffic will be required to establish connections to ZooKeeper and update locked node states inside ZooKeeper. This is as frequent as the current calls made to the database to lock nodes. Performance Impact ------------------ * This code reduces the number, and complexity, of database calls needed for acquiring a lock on a node if enabled. There is still a need for a single call to the database via `objects.Node.get(node_id)` to retrieve a copy of the node object to return to the `ZooKeeperSyncManager`'s caller. * This changeset is primarily focused on how to release a lock. If there is a network partition, or some other crash of a conductor, all locks on the nodes acquired by that conductor should be released. ZooKeeper has a very convenient feature known as `Ephemeral Nodes`_ [3] that only exist for the lifetime of a client's session that created it. This means that if a client, for whatever reason, disconnects, the Ephemeral Nodes it created will be destroyed. If these Ephemeral Nodes are used to create a locking construct, then these locks can be trusted to be released in the event of a conductor dying during a workload, or due to a network partition. Other deployer impact --------------------- * Config option: `ironic.sync_managers.backend` - specifies the type of `SyncManager` that will be used to handle the distributed locking. The default is `dbapi` which uses database backed locking. This spec plans to introduce a value, `zookeeper`, which will enable the `SyncManagerProxy` to use the `ZooKeeperSyncManager`. * Config option: `ironic.sync_managers.zookeeper_hosts` - specifies a comma delimited list of `host:port` pairs for the ZooKeeper client to connect to. * This feature has to be explicitly enabled in `setup.cfg`. * ZooKeeper server(s) will need to be run in conjunction to enabling this sync manager backend. A `ZooKeeper Ensemble`_ [4] can be ran with only a single host, however, there are downsides to that approach that operators need to undestand. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- kylestev Primary assignee: kylestev Work Items ---------- * Implement `ZooKeeperSyncManager` class which handles locking with Kazoo as the backend. * Write the tests for the `ZooKeeperSyncManager` class. * Add the proper documentation and configuration options for deployers to easily adopt this change if it is merged. Dependencies ============ * This spec depends on: `Pluggable Distributed Synchronization`_ [1] being accepted, implemented, and merged. * Requires the Python library `kazoo`_ [5] for interacting with ZooKeeper. * Kazoo is in the `global requirements`_ [6] for OpenStack Testing ======= Standard unit testing should suffice. There will be no Tempest tests added as this spec does not expose any public interfaces. Documentation Impact ==================== * ZK plugin conf * Minimal quickstart guide on setting up a ZooKeeper Ensemble? References ========== [1] .. _`Pluggable Distributed Synchronization`: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/pluggable-distributed-synchronization [2] .. _`StackForge Tooz`: https://github.com/stackforge/tooz [3] .. _`Ephemeral Nodes`: http://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.2.1/zookeeperProgrammers.html#Ephemeral+Nodes [5] .. _`ZooKeeper Ensemble`: http://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.1.2/zookeeperAdmin.html#sc_zkMulitServerSetup [5] .. _`kazoo`: https://github.com/python-zk/kazoo [6] .. _`global requirements`: https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/255e626f7a9b92189fc772703b3b57efe1dbd07d/global-requirements.txt#L40

commit_message:
Create 'devref' folder and move version specs to it

Create a specs/devref folder for ongoing reference material.

Move the api-microversions and new-ironic-state-machine specs into this
new folder, while leaving breadcrumbs from the current document
locations.

Since neither spec was actually completed in Kilo, there is no benefit
to keeping these versions of the specs in tree as we iterate and refine
the design. This paves the way for these files to be updated without
needing to whole-sale copy the (incomplete) spec to a new
release-specific folder.

Change-Id: Ibfa8e34c22e9b2706a237c930063cce2c5c27a1c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/54/196254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This design was not fully implemented in Kilo, and has been `moved to the devref section`_ as work on it will span multiple cycles. For a description of work completed in Kilo, please see the `Kilo release notes`_. .. _moved to the devref section: ../devref/new-ironic-state-machine.html .. _Kilo release notes: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ReleaseNotes/Kilo#OpenStack_Bare_Metal_service_.28Ironic.29
deleted_lines: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/new-ironic-state-machine This blueprint suggests reworking the Ironic provisioning state machine to fix some current shortcomings and to make it easier for drivers and external orchestration agents to manage nodes in Ironic. NOTE: This blueprint describes the functionality we intend the new state machine to have. Actual implementation of this spec, including detailed upgrade paths and technical arcana will be handled by other specs. Problem description =================== The current Ironic state machine has a few shortcomings: * NOSTATE is a state that indicates we have no state information about a node. This may be fine for talking about the node's power state, but we should always know what provisioning state a node is in. * We also need a state to put nodes in when they are performing configuration tasks that can reasonably be expected to take hours to complete, such as RAID configuration and burn in. It is unreasonable to force upstream consumers of Ironic managed nodes to wait hours between the time they request a node and get it, so running these tasks as part of DEPLOYING or DEPLOYWAIT is nonviable. * We also need a place to handle node decommissioning tasks. The current decommissioning blueprints handle this add 'decommissioning' and 'decommissioned' states, but it would also be useful to perform decommissioning tasks on freshly-added nodes. * We also need to let external orchestration systems hook into parts of the state machine for each node to let them manage parts of the node life cycle without having to import that functionality into Ironic. Details of how that will happen will be covered in a different spec. Proposed change =============== Current state machine:: NOSTATE//NONE +----------+------+\ [DEPLOYWAIT//DEPLOYDONE] ^ R:active + ^ | | | + v v [DELETING//DELETED] +--->[DEPLOYING//DEPLOYDONE] + ^ | + + | | R:rebuild| | | v | | | v ERROR//NONE | | | DEPLOYFAIL//NONE | | v | +---+ACTIVE//NONE | R:deleted + +---------------------------+ Legend for the current state machine: * [STATE] indicates an active state. Ironic is doing something to the node. * STATE indicates a stable (or passive) state. Ironic will not transition unless receiving a request via the API. * R:request indicates the request which must be passed to the API to initiate a transition out of a stable state. Ironic's API presents two fields for the provision_state of a node: current and target. Thus, in this diagram, all states are represented as "CURRENT-slash-slash-TARGET" state. Descriptions of the states for the current state machine can be found `here <https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/stable/icehouse/ironic/common/states.py>`. New state machine:: ENROLL -----------> [VERIFY*/MANAGEABLE] R:manage | v +------>MANAGEABLE<--------+ | + + ^ | | | R:zap| | | |R:inspect | + | | | | + [ZAP*/MANAGEABLE]<----+ | | +---->[INSPECT*/MANAGEABLE] | | R:provide| +----------+ +-------+ R:manage | v + [CLEAN*/AVAILABLE]+------->AVAILABLE ^ + | |R:active + v [DELET*/AVAILABLE] [DEPLOY*/ACTIVE] ^ + ^ |R:delete | |R:rebuild | v + +------------------+ACTIVE+-----------+ | ^ |R:rescue | | v | + [RESCU*/RESCUE] | [UNRESCU*/ACTIVE] + | ^ | | |R:unrescue | | | v +----------------------+----------+RESCUE Legend for the new state machine: [STATE*/TARGET] STATE* indicates an active state, a momentary state, and a fail state. The active state has an -ING suffix, the momentary state has a -ED suffix, and the fail state has a -FAIL suffix. In the active state, Ironic is doing something to the node. * If the steps taken during the active (-ING) state succeed, Ironic will automatically transition to the momentary (-ED) state and then to the next indicated state on the graph. Unless there are special rules for momentary states, they will not be separately described. * If it fails, Ironic will transition to the fail (-FAIL) state. Unless there are special rules for the fail state, it will not be separately described. TARGET indicates the target state that Ironic will try to transition the node to from the active state. TARGET must be a stable state. STATE A stable (or passive) state, usually the target of a particular set of state transitions. Ironic will not transition away from this state without an API request to do so. R:request Indicates that the transition so labeled happens as a result of this particular API call. Descriptions of the new states: ENROLL This is the state that all nodes start off in. When a node is in ENROLL, the only thing Ironic knows about it is that it exists, and Ironic cannot take any further action by itself. Once a node has its drivers and the required information for each driver in node.properties, the node can be transitioned to VERIFYING via the manage API call VERIFYING Ironic will validate that it can manage the node with the drivers and the credentials it has been assigned. For drivers that manage power state of the node, this must involve actually going out and confirming that the credentials work to access whatever node control mechanism they talk to. MANAGEABLE Once Ironic has verified that it can manage the node using the driver and credentials passed in at node create time, the node will be transitioned to MANAGEABLE and (optionally) powered off. From MANAGEABLE, nodes can transition to: * MANAGEABLE (through ZAPPING) via the zap API call, * MANAGEABLE (through INSPECTING) via the inspect API call, and * AVAILABLE (through CLEANING) via the provide API call. ZAPPING Nodes in the ZAPPING state are performing (potentially) long-running and destructive tasks, such as: * changing RAID levels, * updating firmware, * going through burn in. Management of tasks for ZAPPING shall be handled as outlined in `the zapping spec <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102685/>`_. ZAPPING tasks must not rely on the information in node.properties being correct beyond the information that each driver needs to connect to the system. ZAPFAIL Nodes that transition into ZAPFAIL will automatically enter maintenance mode, as failure to ZAP a machine usually indicates a hardware failure or something else that requires remote hands to fix. INSPECTING INSPECTING will utilize node introspection to update hardware-derived node properties to reflect the current state of the hardware. We expect this state to get its data via the driver introspection interface (reference to spec forthcoming). If introspection fails, the node will transition to INSPECTFAIL. CLEANING Nodes in the CLEANING state are being scrubbed in preparation to being made AVAILABLE. Good candidates for CLEANING tasks include: * Erasing the drives. * Validating firmware integrity. * Verifying that the actual hardware configuration matches what is described in node.properties. * Booting to a `long running deploy ramdisk <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102405/>`_, if you want the machine to stay on while in AVAILABLE. Management of CLEANING tasks should be handled in the same fashion as ZAPPING tasks. No matter what tasks are performed during CLEANING, the apparent configuration of the system must not change. For instance, if you tear down a set of RAID volumes to securely erase each physical disk separately, you must rebuild the RAID volumes you tore down. AVAILABLE Nodes in the AVAILABLE state are cleaned, preconfigured, and ready to be provisioned. From AVAILABLE, nodes can transition to: * ACTIVE (through DEPLOYING) via the active API call. * MANAGEABLE via the manage API call DEPLOYING Nodes in DEPLOYING are being actively prepared to run a workload on them. This should mainly consist of running a series of short-lived tasks, such as: * Setting appropriate BIOS configurations * Partitioning drives and laying down file systems. * Creating any additional resources (node-specific network config, etc.) that may be required by additional subsystems. Tasks for DEPLOYING should be handled in a manner similar to how they are handled for ZAPPING (details to be addressed in a different spec). ACTIVE Nodes in ACTIVE have a workload running on them. Ironic may collect out-of-band sensor information (including power state) on a regular basis, but will otherwise leave them alone. Nodes in ACTIVE can transition to: * RESCUE (through RESCUING) via the rescue API call, * AVAILABLE (through DELETING and CLEANING) via the delete API call, or * ACTIVE (through DEPLOYING) via the rebuild API call. RESCUING Nodes in RESCUING are being booted into a temporary operating environment for troubleshooting or maintenance related reasons. RESCUE RESCUE exists to allow Ironic to be aware of a node that would be otherwise running a workload, but that is booted into a different operating environment for maintenance or troubleshooting reasons. From RESCUE, nodes can transition to: * ACTIVE (through UNRESCUING) via the unrescue API call, or * AVAILABLE (through DELETING and CLEANING) via the delete API call. UNRESCUING Nodes in UNRESCUING are being transitioned back to ACTIVE from RESCUE. Ironic will unwind whatever it needed to do to get the node into RESCUE DELETING Nodes in DELETING state are being torn down from running an active workload. In DELETING, Ironic should tear down or remove any configuration or resources it added in DEPLOYING. Alternatives ------------ No reasonable ones that we could think of at the summit. Data model impact ----------------- Under the current state machine, NOSTATE is represented by a NULL in the database. This will require a database migration to change all NULLs to "AVAILABLE" along with special-case API handling during the migration. The additional states should not require changes to the data model. REST API impact --------------- We will provide the following verbs to manage the node lifecycle in the state machine: +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | Verb | Initial State| Intermediate States | End State | +===========+==============+==========================+===========+ | manage | ENROLL | VERIFYING -> VERIFIED | MANAGEABLE| +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | zap | MANAGEABLE | ZAPPING -> ZAPPED | MANAGEABLE| +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | inspect | MANAGEABLE | INSPECTING -> INSPECTED | MANAGEABLE| +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | provide | MANAGEABLE | CLEANING -> CLEANED | AVAILABLE | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | manage | AVAILABLE | (none) | MANAGEABLE| +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | active | AVAILABLE | DEPLOYING -> DEPLOYED | ACTIVE | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | rebuild | ACTIVE | DEPLOYING -> DEPLOYED | ACTIVE | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | rescue | ACTIVE | RESCUING -> RESCUED | RESCUE | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | unrescue | RESCUE | UNRESCUING -> UNRESCUED | ACTIVE | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | delete | ACTIVE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE | | | | CLEANING -> CLEANED | | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | delete | RESCUE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE | | | | CLEANING -> CLEANED | | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ The API will remain backwards compatible with the active, rebuild, and delete verbs. Unless otherwise required for backwards compatibility, the verbs must be called when the node is in the Initial State, and Ironic will perform all actions and transitions needed to move through the Intermediate States to the End State. Since we are adding new states, older API clients may behave unexpectedly when they encounter a node in a state they do not understand. RPC API impact -------------- Not as a direct impact of this spec (beyond what is mentioned in the REST API impact section), but all the to-be-written specs which will actually implement the new states will have significant RPC and REST api impact. Driver API impact ----------------- Yes. Large swaths of driver code will need a refactor to cooperate with the new per-node state machines. Nova driver impact ------------------ NOSTATE has been renamed to AVAILABLE. This will require some glue code and creating an upgrade path. Security impact --------------- Probably not, assuming perfect coding. Other end user impact --------------------- Yes. Scalability impact ------------------ Probably nothing significant. Performance Impact ------------------ Ditto. Other deployer impact --------------------- Nodes will not automatically transition from ENROLL to MANAGEABLE. Deployers must assign drivers and add credentials to the node and then call the manage API before Ironic can manage the node. Nodes will not automatically transition from MANAGEABLE to AVAILABLE, deployers will need to do that via the API before nodes can be scheduled. Developer impact ---------------- Current and new Ironic drivers will need rework to comply with the new state machine. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None yet. Work Items ---------- Specs need written to hash out the implementation details that the new state machine implies. Dependencies ============ Most every blueprint that touches on the Ironic drivers will be affected, but this blueprint is vendor-agnostic. Testing ======= None for this spec, but the implementation specs will need to address testing impacts of the changes they recommend. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None for this spec, but the implementation specs will need to address upgrade and backwards compatibility. Documentation Impact ==================== This spec should be used as initial documentation for the new state machine. References ========== Anyone have a link to some developer session notes? I was sorta busy being a whiteboard monkey: https://i.imgur.com/tCxUCYk.jpg

commit_message:
Introduce a "living" document for the state machine

This change reverts the kilo-implemented/new-ironic-state-machine spec
back to the contents it had when Kilo was released, while preserving
all changes since then in the new file, state-machine-ref.

Additionally, it updates some sections based on lessons we learned
during Kilo and Liberty, and adds description of API compatibility
requirements around adding new states as an aspiration for work in
Mitaka.

Change-Id: I2a74e590212684325d5a672ef28813578c975184
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/32/212132/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================= Ongoing: New Ironic State Machine =================================This document describes the reworking of the Ironic provisioning state machine to fix some current shortcomings and to make it easier for drivers and external orchestration agents to manage nodes in Ironic. NOTE: This document describes the functionality we intend the new.. note:: Work on this began during the Kilo cycle. .. note:: API version negotiation was implemented, in part, to ease the friction which users experienced as the State Machine was enhanced. In the Juno release, Ironic's state machine has a few shortcomings:Juno state machine ------------------ Juno-era state machine::New state machine ----------------- Descriptions of the new states ------------------------------ State Machine Impact -------------------- Not applicable -- this spec introduced the state machine. As we add new states, older clients can not be expected to interoperate with Nodes in new stable states (ENROLL, MANAGEABLE). Nodes in these state will be hidden from requests for a list of Nodes if the client specified an older API version in the request header. This applies to nodes in transition to one of these states as well (ZAPPING, INSPECTING). Nodes transitioning from DELETING through CLEANING will be listed as though they are still DELETING. If a client, specifying an older API version, requests a Node directly by its name or UUID, and that Node is in a state incompatible with the requested API version, the server shall return an `HTTP 415`_. Unless otherwise required for backwards compatibility, the verbs must be called when the node is in the Initial State, and Ironic will perform all actions and transitions needed to move through the Intermediate States to the End State. The API will remain backwards compatible with the `active`, `rebuild`, and `delete` verbs. It follows that, for any new state transition which is a true subset of states existing previously, the API must continue to allow the previous state changes while hiding the details of the new intermediate states. For example, if a client requests to `delete` a Node while specifying version 1.1, that Node should not appear to transition through any `CLEAN` states -- even if, internally, it does -- because that client can not be expected to interact with states introduced after version 1.1 (eg, the new AVAILABLE state, described below). A further discussion of API versioning `can be found here`_. References to mailing list discussions below. 1: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/065793.html 2: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066957.html .. _HTTP 415: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html#sec10.4.16 .. _can be found here: ./api-version-negotiation.html Client (CLI) impact ------------------- This work introduces several new provisioning actions. As such, the CLI will need to be updated to accept these verbs in the "ironic node-set-provision-state" command.API impact.NOSTATE has been renamed to AVAILABLE. Clients requesting API versions before v1.2 will continue to see the NOSTATE state. The Kilo release of Nova requires a version of python-ironicclient which requests an API version greater than or equal to 1.2, and therefore sees the AVAILABLE state. Nova's virt driver code was updated during Kilo to accept the new state name. The upgrade process for Nova `was described here`_. .. _was described here: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/upgrade-guide.html#upgrading-from-juno-to-kiloThis work should have no direct impact on security. It may have indirect benefits if, at some point, policy settings are enabled which may restrict certain state transitions to only certain users.As we have collectively learned, the workflow changes described by this document have very significant impact on any user or application interacting directly with the Ironic service. Changes in the default state of a Node, or in the semantics of managing a Node, are immediate breaking changes for many users and must be treated as such. Everyone.None associated with this devref. Work items will be attached to the specs which implement subsections of this design.This design reference should be used as initial documentation for the new state machine.

CLEANWAIT Just like the CLEANING state, the nodes in CLEANWAIT are being prepared to become AVAILABLE. The difference is that in CLEANWAIT the conductor is waiting for the ramdisk to boot or the clean step which is running in-band to finish. The API will remain backwards compatible with the active, rebuild, and delete verbs. Unless otherwise required for backwards compatibility, the verbs must be called when the node is in the Initial State, and Ironic will perform all actions and transitions needed to move through the Intermediate States to the End State. Since we are adding new states, older API clients may behave unexpectedly when they encounter a node in a state they do not understand.api impact.NOSTATE has been renamed to AVAILABLE. This will require some glue code and creating an upgrade path.Probably not, assuming perfect coding.Yes.None yet.Specs need written to hash out the implementation details that the new state machine implies.This spec should be used as initial documentation for the new state machine. commit_message:
Major overhaul of our version docs

This is a major overhaul of our documents describing the New State
Machine and API Version Negotiation, based on the ongoing discussions on
the mailing list and elsewhere.

Change-Id: I342f149de91fa698c260837ffecf737d566faac5

commit_message:
Capabilities should accept values as dictionary

This spec proposes to allow capabilities to accept values
as dictionary of strings and json lists.

Change-Id: I340f7f7601f198b8d4981b8dfaccd09eea075bc8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/34/182934/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================================== Capabilities should accept values as dictionary of strings and lists ==================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/capabilities-as-dictionaries The ironic.node['capabilities'] cannot accept the value as a dictionary. This restricts the user for the capabilities with possible multiple values. The nova-ironic-virt driver is also incapable to handle JSON dictionary as capabilities format. https://review.openstack.org/182572 Problem description =================== Today ironic node's node.properties['capabilities'] accepts the value as a string only. So even if there are multiple capabilities keys, it appears as: 'capabilities' = 'k1:v1,k2:v2,k3:v3...kN:vN' The side effects of this form are: * While updating the capabilities manually, operator need to take care of existing capabilities. This is always error prone. * For each key there can be a single value, and it cannot accept multiple values for a key in json list as the parsing is done based on comma and colons. The multiple values could be given with a delimeter/seperator other than comma and colons as below: 'capabilities': 'boot_mode:uefi bios' In above example, space is used as a seperator between two values of boot_mode. The ironic virt driver in nova is also incapable to handle json dictionary of Strings and Lists as the capabilities values format. Proposed change =============== Enhance the node.properties['capabilities'] to accept the value as json Dictionary of strings and List. However the current format parsing should be retained as ironic and nova should work with each other for backward compatibility with current form also. Alternatives ------------ To use current form of data type as strings. pros: None. Cons: String form of capabilities is not scalable, not user friendly to add a new capability, and it cannot handle multiple values for a key. Data model impact ----------------- None. State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- At all the places where capabilities have been parsed/used currently. RPC API impact -------------- At all the places where capabilities have been parsed/used currently. Driver API impact ----------------- At all the places where capabilities have been parsed/used currently. Nova driver impact ------------------ Nova ironic virt driver will require change to accomodate the change in capabilities value format. https://review.openstack.org/182572 Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- This will help in reducing/minimizing issues due to malformed capabilities when capabilities are updated manually. It eases adding a new capability key value pair as compared to editing the capabilities as string. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: agarwalnisha1980 Other contributors: mjturek Work Items ---------- * Modify the parsing for capabilities to dictionary instead of string at all applicable places in ironic. * Allow the parser to parse json list as valid value. Dependencies ============ Requires the following spec to be implemented: https://review.openstack.org/182572 Testing ======= * Unit tests will be added. * tests for different possoble scenarios to test backward and forward compatibility will be done. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== If nova spec https://review.openstack.org/182572 and code merges first, then ironic should not see any compatibility issue. The string format has to be retained for backward compatibility with Nova driver. Documentation Impact ==================== Yes, would need to document possible ways of creating capabilities. References ========== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1421261

subject: Add `memdisk_boot` and support boot Windows PreInstallation EnvironmentWinPE)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-07 06:45:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/commit/c3bd1deebf8fa84076834709e080c6817e5acdad', 'message': 'Add support to boot WinPE

Many users are used to managing their machines by using WinPE.
They have many tools work well in the WinPE system which

commit_message:
Add `memdisk_boot` and support boot Windows PreInstallation
EnvironmentWinPE)

WinPE is a small operating system used to install, deploy, and
repair Windows 8, Windows Server 2012 R2, and other Windows
operating systems.

Many users are used to managing their machines by using WinPE.
They have many tools work well in the WinPE system which
make life easier. So why not provide the functionality in Ironic?

Change-Id: I17bb9f3e5c865f4eec2fc5339cd1b9134edcb4e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/89/220889/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============= Boot WinPE ============= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/boot-winpe This blueprint aims to add support for booting winPE. Problem description =================== Many users are used to managing their machines by using WinPE. They have many tools work well in the WinPE system which make life easier. So why not provide the functionality in Ironic? Proposed change =============== * Add a new boot section named `boot_winpe` to delivery the iso file to hosts. * If deploy_ramdisk is winPE(iso file), Ironic will jump deploy process and directly boot to winPE on hosts and return DEPLOYDONE state. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Admin should add property `iso_ramdisk=true` to deploy_ramdisk images. Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tan-lin-good Work Items ---------- * Add boot section `boot_winpe` Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add unit tests. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== Add the new use case. References ========== A POC is ready: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/220882/1

commit_message:
Mechanism for skipping a clean step on per-node basis

This commit adds support for skipping a clean step
on per-node basis.

Related-bug: #1526760

Change-Id: I89fd0c8d91e658d57fb872727832b5d8639819ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/58/238858/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Mechanism to skip a clean step for a particular node ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/skip-clean-step-for-a-node This spec proposes a mechanism to skip a clean step during automated cleaning for a particular node. Problem description =================== It was noted while working on enabling RAID configuration as an automated clean step that, there is no way to skip a clean step for a particular node. Such a use case might arise, where a deployer might choose not to use RAID, even though there is a RAID controller in the node. Since this might be applicable for any other clean step, a generic mechanism is required for skipping a subset of clean steps on a per-node basis. Proposed change =============== * Add a new API to get/set the list of clean steps that are to be skipped for a particular node. The list of clean steps to be skipped should be in JSON format. See `REST API impact`_ for more information. * Accept the clean steps to be skipped, do possible validation and store it in Ironic DB. See `Data model impact`_ for more information. * During automated cleaning, skip the clean step if it is in list of steps to be skipped and log an info message. * For any clean step in list of steps to be skipped that is not found during automated cleaning, log a warning. Alternatives ------------ * Don't allow any provision in automated cleaning framework for skipping a clean step. Let the clean steps choose whether it needs to be skipped or not depending upon an input in node's field. While this works, the problem might be applicable to more clean steps and such things might need to be repeated. This might confuse the operator. Instead, a generic API to get/set the list of clean steps to be skipped during automated cleaning will help. Data model impact ----------------- A new database table node_skipped_clean_steps will be added. ``node_skipped_clean_steps`` will have the following fields: * node_id references ``nodes.node_id`` * inteface_name * step_name * reason A new field ``skipped_clean_steps`` will be added to the ``Node`` object will be loaded lazily. It will be a dictionary whose key will be interface name and value will be a set containing the names of steps that are skipped. ``reason`` is optional. State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- *POST /v1/nodes/<node_ident>/cleaning/skipped_clean_steps* This will require an argument ``clean_steps_to_skip``. It will be a list of dictionaries containing information about the steps to be skipped. As an example:: { 'clean_steps_to_skip': [{ 'interface': 'raid', 'step': 'create_configuration', 'reason': 'node doesn't have raid controller' }, { 'interface': 'raid', 'step': 'delete_configuration', 'reason': 'node doesn't have raid controller' }] } It will do the following: * Validate the structure of input data (whether it is a list of dictionaries) and if each item has an ``interface`` and ``step`` mentioned in it. * Ironic conductor method invoked (through an RPC call) will validate whether ``interface`` mentioned, is in the list of interfaces for which cleaning is supported. It will also try to query the interface and check if the clean step is correct. If the interface can't get the list of clean steps (because it requires a remote agent to be booted), this validation will be skipped. * After validation, it will be stored in Ironic DB. *GET /v1/nodes/<node_ident>/cleaning/skipped_clean_steps* This will return the contents of list of steps to be skipped stored in Ironic DB. *PATCH /v1/nodes/<node_ident>/cleaning/skipped_clean_steps* This will allow to add/delete one or more clean steps to the list fo clean steps to be skipped As an example:: [ { 'op': 'add', 'interface': 'raid', 'step': 'create_configuration', 'reason': 'node doesn't have raid controller' }, . . . ] Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Support will be added in the CLI for this:: ironic node-skipped-clean-steps-add <node-ident> --step <interface_name>,<step_name>,<reason> [--step <interface_name>,<step_name>,<reason>] ironic node-skipped-clean-steps-remove <node-ident> --step <interface_name>,<step_name> [--step <interface_name>,<step_name> ironic node-get-skipped-clean-steps <node-ident> RPC API impact -------------- One new RPC API will be ``set_clean_steps_to_skip`` which will be used in the API ``POST /v1/nodes/<node_ident>/cleaning/skipped_clean_steps``. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers can use the new API to mention a list of clean steps that should be skipped on a per-node basis. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rameshg87 Work Items ---------- * Add the new RPC API and new API * Make changes in cleaning code in conductor to skip the clean steps. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Since support for skipping clean steps will be added with a new API, it will not impact existing deployments. Documentation Impact ==================== The way to use the feature will be documented. References ========== * Manual cleaning - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/231288

commit_message:
Add service managment API

Proper operation depends on up-to-date information about the
availability of the services running. In environment with more
then one conductor, it's useful to have such information.
Currently there are no quick way to get all Ironic's services
and their status, also it would be  to have enable/disable
service feature for maintenance purposes. So this spec proposes
to add new API for this.

Change-Id: I9262829c800321e2fdd74ac965df133a91e6cb73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/39/230939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========== Service API =========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/services-api This spec propose to add new API for service management. Problem description =================== Proper operation depends on up-to-date information about the availability of the services running. In environment with more then one conductor, it's useful to have such information. Currently there are no quick way to get all Ironic's services and their status, also it would be nice to have enable/disable service feature for maintenance purposes. so this spec proposes to add new API for this. Proposed change =============== - This change propose to add new api extensions for new cmd: * /services * /services/enable * /services/disable - Add new ``disabled`` and ``disabled_reason`` db fields; - To enable/disable functionality HashRing will be changed to get the list of hosts mapped onto driver, except disabled; * get_active_driver_dict() return drivers w/o disabled conductors. - Support new API in ironicclient; - Add tests covered new API. The list cmd output will be following: +--------+-------------+-----------+----------+-------+-------------+---------+ | id | Host | Drivers | Status | State | Updated at | Disabled| | | | | | | | Reason | +--------+-------------+-----------+-------+----------+-------------+---------+ | <uuid> | ironic-cond | <drivers> | disabled | up | 2015-10-05 | - | +--------+-------------+-----------+-----------+--------------------+---------+ | <uuid> | ironic-cond | <drivers> | enabled | up | 2015-10-05 | - | +--------+-------------+-----------+----------+-------+-------------+---------+ Alternatives ------------ - Use third-party monitoring applications Data model impact ----------------- The ``disabled`` and ``disabled_reason`` fields in the Conductor object will be added: disabled = Column(Boolean, default=False) disabled_reason = Column(String(255)) +----------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +----------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ | created_at | datetime | YES | | NULL | | | updated_at | datetime | YES | | NULL | | | disabled | tinyint(1) | YES | | NULL | | | disabled_reason| varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | | | id | int(11) | NO | PRI | NULL | auto_increment | | hostname | varchar(255) | NO | UNI | NULL | | | drivers | text | YES | | NULL | | | online | tinyint(1) | YES | | NULL | | +----------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- New API endpoints would be added: * /services - list all services; * /services/enable - enable service; * /services/disable - disable service; Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Add new API support to client Usage: ironic service-list ironic service-enable <id> ironic service-disable <id> [-r reason] RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Anton Arefiev (aarefiev) Work Items ---------- * Add new API; * Add new fields to db model; * Add new endpoints support to ironicclient; * Cover new functionality with unit tests and tempest. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests would be added, also new tempest. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation of new API should be added. References ========== None

commit_message:
Virtual media drivers to deploy without DHCP

Currently virtual media drivers (iscsi_ilo, agent_ilo,
iscsi_irmc, agent_irmc) drivers use virtual media to boot
the deploy kernel/ramdisk.  The booted kernel/ramdisk fetches
the IP through dhcp. But these drivers can pass the IP details
to deploy kernel/ramdisk via virtual media and do the
provisioning without a dhcp server on the provisioning network.

Change-Id: Ib38751f9d040bd3eaffafbda077fa79bf1c78986
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/67/137567/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Enable iLO virtual media drivers to deploy without dhcp ======================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ilo-virtualmedia-drivers-dhcpless-deploy Currently ``iscsi_ilo`` and ``agent_ilo`` drivers uses virtual media to boot the deploy kernel/ramdisk. Currently the booted kernel/ramdisk fetches the IP through dhcp. But iscsi_ilo driver can pass the IP details to deploy kernel/ramdisk via virtual media (using the ip parameter) and do the provisioning without a dhcp server on the provisioning network. Problem description =================== * DHCP servers are a bootleneck when provisioning large number of nodes. * Some deployers don't want to use DHCP in their data centers due to their network topology. Proposed change =============== This spec tries to address the problem partially by removing the dependency on DHCP for provisioning. When the proposed change in this spec is combined with change proposed to enable config drives in Ironic[1]_, it enables deployers to use Ironic without DHCP using iLO virtual media drivers. The proposed changes are as follows: * Retrieve the IP details from Neutron and pass two new arguments to the deploy kernel/ramdisk. + ``ip=<client-ip>:<boot-server-ip>:<gw-ip>:<netmask>`` + ``BOOTIF=<hardware-address-of-boot-interface>`` The above arguments are similar to what ``syslinux`` would pass when the machine is booted over PXE. * Make changes in Ironic Python Agent to access ``ip`` and ``BOOTIF`` as valid arguments.

subject: Don't immediately null host/node when shelving
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-04 10:03:02.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_shelve.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c455c82dac32f5a0313077ec3bd8aca1f7db1bcb', 'message': "Don't immediately null host/node when shelving

When offloading a shelved instance, resources should be freed. However,
the ability to free resources is dependant on being able to find the
resource tracker for an instance's node. At present, the instance node
and host are nulled before attempting to update the resource tracker,
meaning the resources are never actually freed. Fix this by nullifying
these values *after* resources updates.

Change-Id: I8f91367aacca0c7c673b28b3c844c70c0d12f0a5
Related-bug: #1545675
(cherry picked from commit 59f55a14b5f5396e653d9eb1e5ded31db72f620b)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't immediately null host/node when shelving

When offloading a shelved instance, resources should be freed. However,
the ability to free resources is dependant on being able to find the
resource tracker for an instance's node. At present, the instance node
and host are nulled before attempting to update the resource tracker,
meaning the resources are never actually freed. Fix this by nullifying
these values *after* resources updates.

Change-Id: I8f91367aacca0c7c673b28b3c844c70c0d12f0a5
Related-bug: #1545675
(cherry picked from commit 59f55a14b5f5396e653d9eb1e5ded31db72f620b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/337108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(ndipanov): Free resources from the resource tracker # NOTE(sfinucan): RPC calls should no longer be attempted against this # instance, so ensure any calls result in errors self._nil_out_instance_obj_host_and_node(instance) instance.save(expected_task_state=None)
deleted_lines: instance.host = None instance.node = None # NOTE(ndipanov): This frees the resources with the resource_tracker
