commit_message:
Support node group operations

Specifies blueprint node-group-operations

Change-Id: Ie80f6ff3822aeb784ff15a5486180db5565334b1
Co-Authored-By: Yuriy Zveryanskyy <yzveryanskyy@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Vasyl Saienko <vsaienko@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/79/228379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Support operations on groups of nodes ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/node-group-operations Support group node operations, e.g. a deploy of several nodes with the same configuration - similar to ``nova boot [--min-count|--max-count]`` Problem description =================== Deploying many identical nodes with the same configuration currently requires equal number of almost identical API requests. Waiting for such group of nodes to arrive to a final state requires periodic polling of every node separately too. Also, some sort of internal sync of node states within a group is required to enable multicast fetching of the image https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/multicast-provision Proposed change =============== Allow Ironic service to deploy group of nodes (defined by tag(s)) with same configuration as a single entity. Group of node must obey the same FSM model as individual nodes, moving to a next state in FSM only after all nodes in question have arrived to the same appropriate state. An optional tolerance to failure might be supported as well, declaring operation (partially) successful when at least given number of nodes are in the required state. Alternatives ------------ None except keeping status quo and continuing to require an external orchestration to drive groups of nodes. Data model impact ----------------- An additional table ``node_groups`` is introduced with schema +-------+------+------+-----------+-------+---------+----------+------+ | index | uuid | tags | operation | state | timeout | max_fail | info | +-------+------+------+-----------+-------+---------+----------+------+ This defines the currently running tasks on groups of nodes. Another additional table ``sync_points`` is introduced with schema +-------+-----------+----------+-------+ | index | groupUUID | nodeUUID | state | +-------+-----------+----------+-------+ This is used to sync and update the current state of all the nodes in the group. These would be created empty on DB migration. Existing instances/tables would not be affected. **to be expanded** State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- A new top-level entity `node-group` in the API is required: v1/nodegroups/ It will support most of the ``v1/nodes/`` actions/endpoints that are applicable to all the nodes in the group simultaneously. **to be expanded** * API version should be bumped. As this change does not affect other parts of API and only extends it, bump in microversion only seems enough. * Appropriate additions to CLI/Python API are needed. * Older clients will simply not have access to this new functionality. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Support for node-group entity must be added to Python API. CLI must support working with this additional entity as well. **to be expanded** RPC API impact -------------- New ``group-action`` calls using ``cast()`` are added, mirroring existing node actions and specifying the node-group UUID instead of node one. Each conductor then filters its nodes by tags specified in the node_groups table and applies the required action to them. During upgrade, this functionality might be used when the whole installation is upgraded, as generally nodes in the group might belong to any conductor, including the not yet upgraded one. **to be expanded** Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None for now. Support of simultaneous boot of several instances via virt-driver would require a general rework of Nova virt-driver's API, so it is out of scope of this spec. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ This spec is a prerequisite of enabling image download via multicast, that would improve scalability in the long run. Implementing it will also reduce a number of API calls needed to drive a group of nodes, improving scalability as well. Performance Impact ------------------ * A separate per-group periodic task is running on all conductors. It updates the ``sync_points`` table in accordance to actual status of nodes that are serviced by the given conductor. It also checks if the state after the update is a terminal one (max_failure is reached or all nodes are in some final or required by FSM state) and proceeds with its own nodes accordingly. **to be expanded** Other deployer impact --------------------- **TBD** Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pshchelo Other contributors: yzveryanskyy vdrok Work Items ---------- * create new DB tables and objects * implement new RPC calls and methods * implement FSM for node groups * extend API * extend clients Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest tests utilizing the new extended API/clients will be added using fake driver. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== * Existing clients will continue to operate as before, they will only not have access to the new functionality. Existing unit/functional/integration tests must pass without any modifications. Documentation Impact ==================== API docs must be extended to describe the new additions to API. Client docs must be extended to describe the functionality added. References ========== Mutlicast image downloading https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/multicast-provision

commit_message:
Add spec for user-settable Node affinity

This blueprint proposes to add an optional affinity between Nodes and
Conductors.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/node-affinity

Change-Id: I9ec995cbda32c3d61d26940f7a8440cd01d876ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/63/193263/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== User Settable Node Affinity =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/node-affinity This blueprint proposes to add an optional affinity between Nodes and Conductors. This would be a 1:N mapping, where each node could be assigned to one or more Conductors, and only managed by those Condutors. This association will be settable via the REST API, and the REST API will allow filtering based on a Conductor's identifier. Problem description =================== This addresses two problems present today: * Nova's approach to "high availability" is to limit the failure domain to a single instance of the nova-compute process. That is to say, rather than providing a traditional HA solution for instances (VMs), Nova approaches this by logically limiting machine failure to the instances managed by a single nova-compute process. Ironic has been violating this logical model by assuming HA of the nova-compute process itself, whether that is achieved through haproxy or by running more than one nova-compute process that each expose all Ironic resources. Some issues have been worked around with a `modified ComputeManager`_ but this approach has been repeatedly rejected by Nova. A solution was discussed at the `Vancouver summit`_ but few notes were taken. That discussion is presented in this work. This proposal addresses this by enabling an operator to associate each nova-compute process to a single ironic-conductor, and each Ironic Node to a single ironic-conductor, thus presenting the same failure domain model that operators of Nova expect it to provide today. * For very large Ironic deployments, it is conceivable that different conductors will be in different network segments, or that some Conductors will be physically closer to certain Nodes than others. This proposes a means to associate Nodes to the Condutors which are physically closest, or in the same network segment, so as to allow a single Ironic cluster to manage larger quantities of servers. .. _modified Computemanager: https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/nova/compute/manager.py .. _Vancouver summit: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-nova-resource-tracker Proposed change =============== Enable the association of Nodes to one or more Conductors, and expose this relationship in the REST API. This association will limit the Hash Ring distribution for that node to that set of Conductors, while the remainder of the Hash Ring logic will remain the same. Note that this affinity is purely optional. The table will be created empty, and existing behavior will not be changed when no affinity is set. Alternatives ------------ Stick to the current model, and its limitations. Data model impact ----------------- * Add a relational table to store the node<->conductor affinity:: CREATE TABLE conductor_affinity ( id INT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, node_id INT NOT NULL, conductor_id INT NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY (id), INDEX (node_id), INDEX (conductor_id), CONSTRAINT `conductor_affinity_ibfk_1` FOREIGN KEY (node_id) REFERENCES nodes (id) ON DELETE CASCADE, CONSTRAINT `conductor_affinity_ibfk_2` FOREIGN KEY (conductor_id) REFERENCES conductor (id), ) ENGINE=InnoDB; Note that these foreign key constraints must exist, and enforce two specific behaviors: * deleting a Node will remove its affinity * a Conductor record can not be deleted if any Nodes are still assigned to it * Rename the current `nodes`.`conductor_affinity` field to `last_managed_by` to more accurately reflect what this field indicates -- the `id` of the last conductor which managed this Node. No other change to the behavior of this field is proposed. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- * Add REST API methods for setting Conductor affinity for a specific Node. This will replace the current affinity with the new affinity immediately:: PUT /v1/nodes/NNNN/affinity BODY: { "affinity": ['SomeHost', 'AnotherHost'] } RETURNS: 200 OK on success This method may return an error if the Node is locked, or if any Host specified in the body can not be found. * Add REST API method for getting the Conductor affinity for a specific Node:: GET /v1/nodes/NNNN/affinity { "affinity": ['SomeHost', 'AnotherHost'] } * Add REST API method for retrieving a list of Nodes that have an affinity with the specified Conductor host name:: GET /v1/nodes?affinity=SomeHost RETURNS: { "nodes": [ { "uuid": ..., }, ... ] } * Modify the Nodes REST resource to include a list of Conductor host names in the detailed resource view. * While it is possible to get a lits of the current Conductor hostnames today from the ``/v1/drivers/`` resource, this is inconvenient. Therefor, this change will also introduce a new endpoint for facilitating retrieval of the list of available Conductor hosts directly in the REST API:: GET /v1/conductors/ { "conductors": [ { "hostname": "SomeHost", "drivers": ['foo', 'bar'], "online": 'True', "created_at": ..., "updated_at": ..., },{ "hostname: "AnotherHost", "drivers": ['foo', 'bar'], ... } ] } This method will not accept any parameters, and should not generate any special exceptions. This endpoint will not allow any modifications. The above changes will require an API version bump so that clients can discover their presence or lack thereof. However, these new endpoints are backwards-compatible, and do not need to be hidden from clients requesting a version prior to the version in which they are introduced. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- New methods will be required in the python client and CLI:: $ ironic conductor-list $ ironic node-set-affinity <NODE> <LIST_OF_HOSTS> $ ironic node-clear-affinity <NODE> RPC API impact -------------- * Modify HashRing.get_hosts() to accept a new optional parameter `limit_to` which accepts a list of hosts to limit the mapping onto. This parameter will default to a value of `None`. This will be implemented by computing the XOR between limit_to and all hosts known to the hash ring, and adding the remainder to ignore_hosts. * Modify ConductorManager.iter_nodes() to only fetch Nodes which have an affinity to that Conductor. * Modify ConductorAPI.get_topic_for() to pass the list of Conductor host names to HashRing.get_hosts(), if the list is not empty. Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ This change will enable the nova-compute process to be "pinned" to a set of resources within Ironic, allowing Nova's conceptual model of failure-domains to be mapped onto an Ironic deployment. This may be done through a new Nova CONF option "associated_ironic_conductor" which would map a specific nova-compute process to a specific ironic-conductor process. This approach will be optional and therefor backwards-compatible with current deployments of Nova and Ironic. However, as it will address a `longstanding issue`_ with the `nova.virt.ironic` driver, it is anticipated that many deployers will choose to use this approach once it is available. .. _longstanding issue: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1337461 Security impact --------------- This should have no security impact. Other end user impact --------------------- This should be limited to Operators, and not directly exposed to Users. Scalability impact ------------------ By allowing locality of Nodes to be expressed as an affinity to one or more Conductors, this should allow Ironic to scale out more effecitely in large environments, eg. where the total number of Nodes exceeds reasonable network limitations for a single L2 domain. Performance Impact ------------------ When affinity is not set, this change should have no performance impact. When affinity is set, this change should have a negligible impact. It will add a JOIN on an INTEGER field to certain queries. It will also change the calculation of the Hash Ring, but it should only result in less computations, not more. Other deployer impact --------------------- No new CONF options are required in Ironic. A separate proposal may add a CONF option to Nova. Affinity will default to disabled (represented by an empty table). As such, there is no immediate impact to deployers when upgrading. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- * Rename conductor_affinity field * Modify RPC API and Hash Ring * Create new table * Add new REST API endpoint for conductors * Add new REST API endpoint for affinity * Implement changes in python client and CLI Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unit tests must be added. * DB migration test must be added. * Tempest API tests must be created, which will exercise the API surface with the Fake driver running on a single host. * Functional testing with real drivers is not necessary, as this does not impact deployment. * Testing with multiple Conductor hosts should be done, but will require a multi-node deployment, which we do not have support for at this time. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Upgrade will involve a DB migration, but should not affect existing tables and therefor should be quick. Documentation Impact ==================== The new REST API will be auto-documented; samples must be added inline. The new CLI option documentation must be added to the CLI. The operator documentation should be updated to describe how to effectively use this feature with Nova. References ========== 1. https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/nova/compute/manager.py 2. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-nova-resource-tracker 3. https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1337461

commit_message:
Using multicast for image transfer

Related Blueprint: multicast-provision

Change-Id: Ic936100ea2b17c192d342a95bde8e8cdf7accc49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/70/225570/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Using multicast for image transfer ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/multicast-provision This blueprint adds support of multicast transport during User Image file transfer. Problem description =================== In huge environments network is bottleneck during simultaneous node provisioning. By starting group deployment over multicast will minimize network utilization. And will minimize resource utilization on image storing servers. Proposed change =============== Baremetal nodes that are spawned with the same user image may be grouped. Since user image is equal on all nodes there is no need to send it by unicast directly to each node. Rather ironic should wait until all nodes in the group are ready to receive user image. Once it is done "user image" should be transfered to all nodes simultaneously via multicast. Alternatives ------------ Continue to use unicast model. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ Simultaneous deployment of same use image will be faster. Performance Impact ------------------ Less load on data store server/network during simultaneous deployment of same image. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Unittests will be added. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== References ==========

commit_message:
New meter for Node Manager

This spec add Node Manager data to achieve same meters as Ceilometer
IPMI agent

Change-Id: I486d569257571a7330818ebe21b4f70dd0dd4337
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/09/176109/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Node Manager Meters =================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/node-manager-meters This blueprint will add Node Manager meters besides current IPMI sensor data and send them to Ceilometer. Problem description =================== Ceilometer has an IPMI agent to fetch same sensor data as Ironic in case of no Ironic deployment. End user should achieve same data via either Ironic or Ceilometer IPMI agent. Ceilometer IPMI agent introduced Node Manager meter recently including airflow and CPU/IO/Mem usage, which is very useful for cloud management. It's confused for end uer to get different data from Ironic, so same Node Manager meters should be added in Ironic. Proposed change =============== Extends get_sensors_data of all the IPMI interface, like IPMIManagement and NativeIPMIManagement, to fetch extra Node Manager data. This would append more Sensor Type like airflow, CPU/IO/Mem usage. Add 'node_manager' as capability in node.properties, and set it to Ture for Node Manager capable machine. get_sensors_data would check this then call the IPMI command to get the Node Manager data. This would introduce node manager meters like: :: | Name | Description | hardware.ipmi.node.temperature | Inlet temperature of the system | hardware.ipmi.node.outlet_temperature | Outlet temperature of the system | hardware.ipmi.node.power | Current power of the system | hardware.ipmi.node.airflow | Volumetric airflow of the system | hardware.ipmi.node.cups | CUPS(Compute Usage Per Second) index data | hardware.ipmi.node.cpu_util | CPU CUPS utilization | hardware.ipmi.node.mem_util | Memory CUPS utilization | hardware.ipmi.node.io_util | IO CUPS utilization So extra sensor types for each meter would be added in the mesg payload. Alternatives ------------ Alternative way is add a new vendor driver to provide vendor fucntion for fetching Node Manager data. This vendor function should be decorated with @base.driver_periodic_task. But it requires setup IPMI environment, e.g. username and crentials, which requires extra work. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ Have some performance impact due to extra task added in periodic task. Other deployer impact --------------------- New configuration of node_manager, default off, is added. Admin can set it for node manager capable machine in deployment. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <edwin.zhai@intel.com> Work Items ---------- - Extends get_sensors_data of all the IPMI interface to fetch extra Node Manager data - Add 'node_manager' as capability in node.properties to indicate the Node Manager support Dependencies ============ Ironic sensor data parsing code in Ceilometer need update to handle new Node Manager data format. Testing ======= Unit test is needed to verify new code path and data format. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== These new Node Manager data requires new sensor data parsing code in Ceilometer, otherwise new Node Manager data sample will be absent in Ceilometer. Documentation Impact ==================== doc/admin-guide-cloud/telemetry/tables/ceilometer-measurements-ironic.xml need update for new Node Manager meters. References ========== None

commit_message:
iLO Node discovery

Implements: Blueprint ilo-node-discovery

Change-Id: I08214cff7f262c3bf170525d5dfe36490c297ffe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/88/109088/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================== iLO Node discovery ==================== Blueprint URL: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ilo-node-discovery This proposal adds the ability to perform out-of-band node discovery via multicast search for ProLiant nodes. Multicast search will be faster than broadcast search. Problem description =================== Today, Ironic does not have the out-of-band node discovery. It cannot discover the nodes with in a subnet range or for a specific driver. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to do node discovery via iLO driver. * ironic driver-vendor-passthru <driver_name> <method> [<arg=value> [<arg=value> ...]] where driver_name=ilo method = node_discovery() arg=value pairs can be like: ["manufacturer"="hp", "node_model" = ["SL", "DL", "BL"] It discovers all ProLiant nodes' iLO IP address that matches the node search identifiers. A deployer can then use the returned node iLO IP address to create nodes. This feature can be used with Node property discovery during node create feature to automate node create. iLO specific module changes: ---------------------------- * Add new method node_discovery() in driver_vendor_passthru() in iLO driver. Alternatives ------------ nmap() can be used to discover Proliant iLOs but it broadcasts which will be slower than multicast. Data model impact ----------------- None. Ironic CLI impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Nisha Agarwal Co-Contributor Wan-Yen Hsu Work Items ---------- * Implement driver_vendor_passthru for iLO driver and add a new method node_discovery() to support the functionality. Dependencies ============ * iLODriver implements the functionality targeted for HP ProLiant servers with iLO4 and above. * Depends on proliantUtils library. (https://github.com/hpproliant/proliantutils) Testing ======= Unit tests will be added conforming to ironic testing requirements. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Deleting instances at any stage of the deployment

Nova expects to be able to delete an instance even when it's spawning
but in Ironic only nodes in DEPLOYWAIT state are allowed to be aborted
mid-deployment. This blueprint adds support for deleting an instance
at any stage of the deployment meeting nova's expectations.

Change-Id: Id53002e2e73289b1682f496ebf694d897b714f25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/62/204162/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================== Lazy delete instances ===================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/lazy-delete-instances This blueprint adds support for deleting an instance at any stage of the deployment. Problem description =================== Nova expects to be able to delete an instance even when it's spawning but in Ironic the deployment can only be stopped in a specific stage (when the node is in ``DEPLOYWAIT`` state). We should allow deleting the instance at any time Proposed change =============== The propose implementation consists in allowing the **deleted** verb for provison state to be passed to a node in in ``DEPLOYWAIT`` or ``DEPLOYING`` provision state. The way the instance is deleted depends on the state of the node. For nodes in ``DEPLOYWAIT`` provison state its pretty straight forward since they don't hold any locks nor there's a thread running in the ``ironic-conductor`` executing the code for the deployment. So for nodes in ``DEPLOYWAIT`` provison state tate we can simple move it to ``DEPLOYFAIL`` state and proceed with cleaning (we acquire a lock before to prevent any race condition in case the ramdisk talks to the ``ironic-conductor`` to continue the deployment). For nodes in ``DEPLOYING`` provision state the deletion of the instance should happen asynchronously, we first need to mark the node in the database to say that the instance will be deleted and have a periodic task which will eventually look at the nodes needing deletion and will perform it. To mark the node this spec proposes adding a new field to the node object called ``delete_instance`` which holds a boolean value indicating whether the instance should be deleted or not. It's important to not that the periodic task will **only** act in the node when it can actually get a exclusive lock on it. So if the node is in ``DEPLOYING`` provision state - which already holds an exclusive lock - it's possible that the node provision state become ``ACTIVE`` before the deletion happens. If the deployment of the node happens in multiple phases, it's likely that once a node enters in ``DEPLOYWAIT`` provision state - which doesn't hold a exclusive lock - the deletion will be performed on this stage before the node ever goes to ``ACTIVE``. In the Nova perspective a successful call to delete whether it happens immediately (``DEPLOYWAIT``) or eventually (``DEPLOYING``) is enough to indicate that the instance have been deleted successfully. Alternatives ------------ * It would be possible to implement a mechanism in Nova which will first ask the driver whether it's possible to delete an instance being instantiated instead of marking the instance straight away as ``deleting`` and tell call destroy() expecting the driver to handle it. * In theory we could implement the deletion of an instance to be always synchronous and have a mechanism to stop the thread that is executing the code which is deploying the node. But I find it more difficult since it would involve breaking the lock and also we have to make sure we route the message from the ``ironic-api`` server to the ``ironic-conductor`` which is doing that work, even after a hash-ring rebalance (that's possible just by routing the message to the conductor which is set in the node's ``reservation`` field) Data model impact ----------------- A new field ``delete_instance`` will be added to the Node table. This field will hold a boolean value indicating whether the deployment should be lazyly deleted or not. State Machine Impact -------------------- We need to allow the verb ``deleted`` to nodes in ``DEPLOYING`` state. REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- We should expose the new ``delete_instance`` field for the nodes resources. RPC API impact -------------- None. We can continue to use ``do_node_tear_down`` for this. Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ The Nova driver won't need to rely more on waiting for the node to get to a specific state before returning from destroy(). Once the command to delete the instance (CLI: ironic node-set-provision-state <node uuid> deleted) runs successfully Nova can assume that the instance will be deleted, whether it happens immediately (``DEPLOYWAIT``) or eventually (``DEPLOYING``) should not matter for Nova. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: lucasagomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com> Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * Add a new field called ``delete_instance`` in the Node's table with migration scripts. * Allow the verb ``deleted`` to nodes in ``DEPLOYING`` state. * Create a periodic task that will be responsible for deleting the instances asynchronously. * Change the Nova driver to not wait on the provision state of the node when deleting an instance. * Change the python-ironicclient to expose the new field ``delete_instance`` for the node resource. Dependencies ============ * This patch depends on the blueprint `ipxe-dymic-config <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/177726/>`_ that makes the iPXE configuration files to be dynamically generated. Testing ======= Unittests will be added for all the projects involved. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None If you have an old version of the Nova Ironic driver and a new Ironic version, in the old Nova Ironic driver _unprovision() will never be called for nodes in ``DEPLOYING`` state so the deletion of the instance will never reach the ``ironic-conductor``. [1] For new version of the Nova Ironic driver and old versions of Ironic, deleting a node in ``DEPLOYING`` state will fail making the ``nova delete`` command to fail. [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/76a97a8d7a04d5e425012ded5ec69cc05765588f/nova/virt/ironic/driver.py#L865-L869 Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation will add explaining for deployers how the lazyly deleation of an instance works. References ==========

commit_message:
Remove Sensor RecordID from IPMI Sensor ID

Initial Design Specification for blue print change-ipmi-sensor-id-name

Change-Id: Ibfa6be999e267bee9437accf100a67247f921996
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/70/130070/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Remove Sensor RecordID from IPMI Sensor ID ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/change-ipmi-sensor-id-name The current name for sensors created by the ipmitool driver contains an IPMI specific sensor record index in addition to the standard IPMI sensor ID. In order to provide consistent naming for sensors across drivers, I would like to change the ipmitool driver to use just the sensor ID (without the record index) for the name of sensor. Problem description =================== If there are multiple providers for sensors, the naming of sensors on a given platform should be consistent so users and providers see equivalent naming for sensors independent of the provider. The ipmitool driver is reporting sensors with an ipmitool specific Sensor ID instead of the standard IPMI Sensor ID. Proposed change =============== I would like to remove the IPMI Sensor Number " (0x##)" from the Sensor ID used as the dictionary index for sensors returned to the ironic conductor by the ipmitool driver. The ipmitool returned Sensor ID with the " (0x##)" will still be available in the resource_metadata 'Sensor ID' field. The " (0x##)" portion of the 'Sensor ID' is an ipmitool artifact which is tacked onto the end of the standard IPMI Sensor ID. By having IPMI use the standard Sensor ID in its return dictionary, users and other provider drivers will see consistent sensor naming on any given platform. Note: If the ipminative driver were to produce sensors, it would name the sensors using the standard IPMI Sensor ID. This change will also affect the user visible Ceilometer name for sensors. With the removal of " (0x##)", consumers will see a name like the following, "hardware.temperature.system_board" instead of the following sensor name "hardware.temperature.system_board_(0x16)". Alternatives ------------ With the need to support more than just an IPMI sensor provider, the names of sensors is going to change. Given there will be a change to sensor names, it seems like having consistent naming is worthwhile. I don't see any alternatives other than leaving the sensor name as it now stands. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- As long as a consumer of Ceilometer sensors doesn't parse the name, backward compatibility will be maintained as the information in the sensor will not change. Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- This change should be done in conjunction with the other blueprints for supporting alternative sensor providers. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <jmank@hp.com> Other contributors: <None> Work Items ---------- * Remove the " (0x##)" component from the 'Sensor ID' returned by ipmitool to the ironic ipmitool driver and use the resulting name as the Sensor ID field in the dictionary returned to the Ironic conductor. Dependencies ============ This change should be done in conjunction with the following blueprints * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/support-per-driver-sensor-meters * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/generic-notification-sensor-meter-plugin * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/send-ilo-health-metrics-to-ceilometer Testing ======= Existing tests will be run and updated as necessary. Specific hand testing will also be done using Proliant platforms. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== This changes should be done in conjunction with the other ironic blueprints specified in the Dependencies section. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * [openstack-dev] [Ironic][Ceilometer] Proposed Change to Sensor meter naming in Ceilometer http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/048631.html

commit_message:
Indicate the deploy progress

Show the progress of the deployment, to give user more information
especially for long-time operation. This will also helpful to analysis
if something wrong in the deploy process.

Change-Id: I1a13bd27378b4335becdd2c3283ff6e0c1384725
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/40/132740/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Indicate the Deploy Progress ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/deploy-progress Show the progress of the deployment, to give user more information especially for long-time operation. This will also helpful to analysis if something wrong in the deploy process. Problem description =================== Some of the deployment operation like copy the image will takes a long time, and currently user have no idea of the progress of the deployment. Also sometimes something may be wrong in the deploy process, and user gave no easy way to find out on which steps the error happens. Proposed change =============== The first change is to provide a field to the node object/DB to save the progress. A 'deploy_progress' field will be added. The second change is to provide an interface so that end user can check the deploy progress. The third change is to add a generic function call to update the deploy progress field. It can be a normal function call and a decoration. The forth change is to enhance some deply function calls like iscsi_deploy.cache_instance_image() to update the deploy progress. I'm not sure if this proposal is aligned with ironic's mission and scope, so I stop here according to the template, to get feedback from the ironic-drivers and ironic-core teams before fleshing out all the details below. Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Has someone else done this thing in another project? In another language? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change? * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated? For example, if you need to take into account existing instances, or modify other existing data, describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- Each API method which is either added or changed should have the following * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does, suitable for use in user documentation. * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE/PATCH) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included. Describe semantic errors which can cause it, such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when a resource is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema defintion do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * Parameters which can be passed via the url, including data types * JSON schema definition for the body data if allowed * JSON schema definition for the response data if any * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. * Is a corresponding change in the client library and CLI necessary? * Is this change discoverable by clients? Not all clients will upgrade at the same time, so this change must work with older clients without breaking them. Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted. Use of free-form JSON dicts should only be permitted where necessary to allow divergence in the drivers. In such case, the drivers must expose the expected content of the JSON dict and an ability to validate it. Reuse of existing predefined parameter types is highly encouraged. RPC API impact -------------- Changes which affect the RPC API should be listed here. For example: * What are the changes, if any, to existing API calls? * What new API calls are being added? Will these be using cast() or call()? * ironic-api and ironic-conductor services must be upgradable independently. What is the upgrade process for rolling this change out to an existing deployment? Driver API impact ----------------- Changes which affect the driver API have a direct effect on all drivers, and often have a wider impact on the system. There are several things to consider in this section. * Is it a change to a "core" or "common" API? * Can all drivers support it initially, or is it specific to a particular vendor's hardware? * How will it be tested in the gate and in third-party CI systems? * If adding a new interface, explain the intended scope of the proposed interface, what functionality it enables, why it is needed, and whether it is supported by current drivers. * If adding or changing a method on an existing interface, the impact on existing drivers should be explored. * Will the new interface or method need to be invoked when the hash ring rebalances, for example to rebuild local state on a new conductor service? * How does this affect upgrades? Third-party drivers could be updated independently from this change, and care must be taken not to break backwards-compatibility within our Driver API. Nova driver impact ------------------ Chances are, if this change affects the REST or Driver APIs, it will also affect the Nova driver in some way. If this requires a functional change in Nova, chances are the Nova team will require a spec to discuss the changes to their project as well. Provide a link to that here, or a justification for why that is not needed. Questions which need to be addressed in this section include: * What is the impact on Nova? * If this change is enabling new functionality exposed via Nova, this section should cite the relevant components within other Nova drivers that alraedy implement this. * Ironic and Nova services must be upgradable independently. If the change affects existing functionality of the nova.virt.ironic driver, how will an upgrade be performed? How will it be tested? Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or credentials? * Does this change affect the accessibility of hardware managed by Ironic? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-ironicclient? What does the user interface there look like? * Will this require changes in the Horizon panel, or any other OpenStack project? Scalability impact ------------------ Describe any potential scalability impact on the system, for example any increase in network, RPC, or database traffic, or whether the feature requires synchronization across multiple services. Examples of things to consider here include: * Additional network calls to internal or external services. * Additional disk or network traffic that will be required by the feature. * Any change in the number of physical nodes which can be managed by each conductor service. Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A periodic task might look like a small addition, but all periodic tasks run in a single thread so a periodic task that takes a long time to run will have an effect on the timing of other periodic tasks. * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impact on performance. * Calls which result in one or more database queries (whether in the api or conductor services) can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any TaskManager locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? * How will the new code be affected if the hash ring rebalances while it is running? Other deployer impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example, a flag that other hardware drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values appropriate for production? Provide an explanation of why these defaults are reasonable. * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after it's merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change adds a new service that deployers will be requried to run, how would it be deployed? Describe the expected topology, for example, what network connectivity the new service would need, what service(s) it would interact with, how many should run relative to the size of the deployment, and so on. * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we were to change the directory that PXE boot files were stored in, how would we update existing boot files created before the change landed? Would we require deployers to manually move them? Is there a special case in the code, which would be removed after some deprecation period? Would we require operators to delete and recreate all instances in order to perform the upgrade? Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other drivers would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in Ironic, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Ironic, document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? * Does this feature target specific hardware? If so, is it a common standard (eg IPMI) or a vendor-specific implementation (eg iLO)? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc)? Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Care must be taken to support our users by not breaking backwards compatibility with either REST API or Driver API changes. * If your proposal includes any changes to the REST API, describe how existing clients will continue to function when interacting with an upgraded API server. * If your proposal includes any changes to the Driver API, describe how existing driver implementations will continue to function when loaded by a conductor running with the new driver base class. * Describe what testing you will be adding to ensure that backwards compatibility is maintained. * If deprecating an existing feature or API, describe the deprecation plan, and for how long compatibility will be maintained. Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Send iLO health metrics to ceilometer

  Updated Design Specification for blue print

Change-Id: I83530fd80c7f18534a922222675dc42d1ee34daa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/78/127378/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Send iLO health metrics to Ceilometer ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/send-ilo-health-metrics-to-ceilometer This blueprint is for the implementation of an iLO ManagementInterface which will implement a get_sensors_data method to collect platform health information from iLO via RIBCL. Problem description =================== The ProLiant platform management system supports reporting information pertaining to the health of platform components. I would like to provide this health information to users by propagating platform health information to Ceilometer as sensors in the same way IPMI sensor information is being sent to Ceilometer. Proposed change =============== Modify the PXEAndIloDriver, IloVirtualMediaIscsiDriver and IloVirtualMediaAgentDriver to use an IloIPMIManagement interface which will implement the get_sensors_data interface to return both iLO reported health sensor information and IPMI sensor information. The IloIPMIManagement interface will be derived from the existing IPMIManagement interface and the get_sensors_data interface will be implemented to call an iLO specific get_sensors_data implementation in addition to calling the IPMIManagement get_sensors_data interface. The IloIPMIManagement interface will return a sensor dictionary containing both the iLO and IPMI sensor information. The sensor dictionary returned by get_sensors_data() will remain in the same base format that is currently defined for IPMI sensors. In order to differentiate sensors in the returned dictionary as coming from different sources, I propose prefixing returned 'Sensor Type' with a per driver unique identifier, driverID. For IPMI, the driverID would be 'ipmi." and for iLO, the driverID would be "ilo.". The driverID must be [a-z] only and the dot postfix is used to delimit the driverID and the Sensor ID. The following shows an example returned sensor dictionary with one Sensor Type from IPMI and one Sensor Type from iLO. :: { 'ipmi.Sensor Type 1': { 'Sensor ID 1': { 'Sensor Reading': 'value units', 'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2' }, 'Sensor ID 2': { 'Sensor Reading': 'value units', 'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2' } }, 'ilo.Sensor Type 2': { 'Sensor ID 3': { 'Sensor Reading': 'value units', 'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2' }, 'Sensor ID 4': { 'Sensor Reading': 'value units', 'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2' } } } Using a prefix on the Sensor Type will effect the Sensor Type names specified in the [conductor] configuration "send_sensor_data_types" list. As currently defined, this list contains only a set of Sensor Types supported by IPMI (Temperature, Fan, Voltage and Current). With the addition of driverID to the Sensor Type, this [conductor] configuration parameter should be to be changed to contain (ipmi.Temperature, ipmi.Fan, ipmi.Voltage and ipmi.Current). This proposed change cannot be enabled until changes are made to the ironic Conductor and Ceilometer to support collecting sensor information from a source other than IPMI. See the following blueprint dependencies needed to implement the complete solution. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/support-per-driver-sensor-meters https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/generic-notification-sensor-meter-plugin Alternatives ------------ The IloIPMIManagement interface could independently send iLO health sensor information directly to Ceilometer itself via its own notification instead of appending health sensor information to the IPMI sensor information. This would accomplish the goal, but would require iLO to have its own notifier and Ceilometer notification plugin. Having each driver do it own notifications and plugin would be replicating capabilities already available in the IPMI sensor implementation. Another approach would be for the IloIPMIManagement interface to send all the iLO reported sensor information instead of appending the iLO health sensor information to the IPMI sensor information. The iLO reported sensors contain different information than what is available via IPMI. If we didn't send IPMI sensor information, this implementation would not be backward compatible with the prior release. The following are an example of the same Temperature Sensor as reported by IPMI and the iLO RIBCL interface we are using to get health information. IPMI Temperature Sensor 10 (as currently recorded in Ceilometer) :: { "counter_name": "hardware.ipmi.temperature", "user_id": null, "resource_id": "cfe2650c-5747-4440-805b-20446f509054-16-system_board_(0x15)", "timestamp": "2014-10-08T18:54:01.169345", "recorded_at": "2014-10-08T18:54:05.704644", "message_id": "7a0226e8-4f1c-11e4-8958-e4115ba9ae71", "source": "openstack", "counter_unit": "C", "counter_volume": 30.0, "project_id": null, "resource_metadata": { "Status": "ok", "Sensor ID": "16-System Board (0x15)", "Entity ID": "66.2 (Baseboard/Main System Board)", "Event Message Control": "Entire Sensor Only", "Readable Thresholds": "ucr unr", "Positive Hysteresis": "Unspecified", "host": "None.localhost", "Sensor Type (Threshold)": "Temperature (0x01)", "Negative Hysteresis": "Unspecified", "Threshold Read Mask": "ucr unr", "Maximum sensor range": "Unspecified", "event_type": "hardware.ipmi.metrics.update", "Sensor Reading": "30 (+/- 0) degrees C", "Minimum sensor range": "-127.000", "Settable Thresholds": "" }, "counter_type": "gauge" } ILO Temperature Sensor 10 :: { "counter_name": "hardware.ilo.temperature:10", "user_id": null, "resource_id": "1af05546-b52f-467c-8b52-6537b5bf0c9b", "timestamp": "2014-10-08T20:46:14.468311", "recorded_at": "2014-10-08T20:46:15.286326", "message_id": "24f0cec4-4f2c-11e4-ae7b-e4115ba9ae71", "source": "openstack", "counter_unit": "Celsius", "counter_volume": 27.0, "project_id": null, "resource_metadata": { "Status": "OK", "Sensor ID": "10", "Label": "VR P1Mem Zone", "Critical": "100 Celsius", "Caution": "95 Celsius", "Location": "System", }, "counter_type": "gauge" } The following are some example of iLO reported health information ILO Temperature Health Example :: { "counter_name": "hardware.ilo.health:overall", "user_id": null, "resource_id": "1af05546-b52f-467c-8b52-6537b5bf0c9b", "timestamp": "2014-10-08T20:46:14.468311", "recorded_at": "2014-10-08T20:46:14.712377", "message_id": "24eff9e0-4f2c-11e4-ae7b-e4115ba9ae71", "source": "openstack", "counter_unit": "Percentage", "counter_volume": 100.0, "project_id": null, "resource_metadata": { "Sensor ID": "Overall", "PlatformName": "ProLiant ML110 G7", "PlatformUUID": "37363536-3636-4D32-3232-303130324A41" }, "counter_type": "gauge" } { "counter_name": "hardware.ilo.health:temperature", "user_id": null, "resource_id": "1af05546-b52f-467c-8b52-6537b5bf0c9b", "timestamp": "2014-10-08T20:46:14.468311", "recorded_at": "2014-10-08T20:46:14.739547", "message_id": "24f0084a-4f2c-11e4-ae7b-e4115ba9ae71", "source": "openstack", "counter_unit": "Percentage", "counter_volume": 100.0, "project_id": null, "resource_metadata": { "Sensor ID": "Temperature", "PlatformName": "ProLiant ML110 G7", "PlatformUUID": "37363536-3636-4D32-3232-303130324A41" }, "counter_type": "gauge" } Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The current sensor naming strategy in Ceilometer is not consumer friendly and in supporting sensors from multiple producers we may want to change to a more consistent naming strategy for all sensors. I submitted a Ceilometer and ironic bug with a proposed solution for sensor naming which resulted in a quick fix to Ceilometer for Juno leaving the remaining naming issues to be addressed separately. See: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1377157 Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The current configuration options for enabling, filtering, and sending sensor information is currently conductor based. I have no specific plans to change this, but as more drivers implement the ability to return sensor information, maybe the configuration options should be driver based. With the addition of 'driverID." prefixing of the 'Sensor Type' names, users which specify the conductor configuration option send_sensor_data_types should update their configuration to identify that the sensors they want to send are specifically "ipmi." sensor types. Alternatively, we could programatically assume that any non prefixed Sensor Type name is always driveID "ipmi." to alleviate the need for the configuration option to be changed by the user. Developer impact ---------------- When this is implemented, the ironic conductor and the ironic Ceilometer notification plugin will need to be changed for this code to be enabled. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <jmank> Other contributors: <None> Work Items ---------- * Propose and get agreement on a standard for the naming of sensor meters in Ceilometer than can support sensors from more than one ironic driver * Proposal: All Sensor Types must be prefixed with a unique sensor source identifier followed by the actual Sensor Type. * IPMI Sensor Types would be: ipmi.Temperature, ipmi.Fan, ... * ILO Sensor Types would be : ilo.Temperature, ilo.Fan, ilo.Health,... * create an IloSensor class to encapsulate acquisition and conductor formatting of iLO health information. This class will implement the get_sensors_data interface which will be used by the IloIPMIManagement class * create an IloIPMIManagement class which is derived from the IloIPMIManagement class. This class will instantiate an IloSensor class during initialization the resulting instantiated class will be used to acquire iLO sensor information in its get_sensors_data interface. Dependencies ============ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/support-per-driver-sensor-meters * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/generic-notification-sensor-meter-plugin * This feature will require a functional change to the python proliantutils to support the RIBCL command to get ProLiant platform health information. * The needed addition to proliantutils to support this is currently in review Testing ======= Unit tests will be need to be added to verify the new code paths. In order to verify correct operation of the full capabilities, ProLiant platform hardware will be necessary and for the time being this will have to accomplished through 3rd party testing. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Backward compatibility can be maintained by assuming that any Sensor ID without a deviceID prefix in send_sensors_data_types is an ipmi Sensor ID. Documentation Impact ==================== The only document that I know needs to be updated will be the ironic doc/source/deploy/intsall-guide.rst. This will need to be updated to document all customer visible changes associated with this work. References ========== None

subject: Add console log support

This design spec introduces the console log support in Ironic.
It specifies how to log the console and retrieve the console
log output. It includes adding new functions in the common
driver interface, adding new REST API to get console log
as well as implementing the new functions in ipmitool and
ipminative drivers.

commit_message:
Add console log support

This design spec introduces the console log support in Ironic.
It specifies how to log the console and retrieve the console
log output. It includes adding new functions in the common
driver interface, adding new REST API to get console log
as well as implementing the rpc topic for console to select
the original conductor.

Related-bug: #1526368

Change-Id: I579d1572b55c894da4af73ad3ff48a2dfa0de4a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/86/164586/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Manage Console Log ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/console-log This blueprint will introduce functions to save, retrieve and clean up the console log for a bare metal node. Problem description =================== Sometimes, the user needs to get console output to debug problems occurred at the node deployment phase. However, some service processors such as BMC do not keep the console log internally. Nova also need console log interface from ironic to retrieve log output. Proposed change =============== * Configuration options for console log server. The following new configuration options will be added: :: [console] console_log_mode=all/none/on_enabled console_log_location=<path to a directory> The ``console_log_mode`` option can have the following values: - ``all`` (default), the drivers will save the console output of all bare metal nodes into log files. - ``on_enabled``, the drives will only save the console output for those nodes whose ``console_enabled`` value is true in the node table. - ``none``, the drivers will not save any console output. The ``console_log_location`` configuration specifies the path to the console log files that should be stored on the ironic-conductor host. The format of console log file name will be ``console_log_location/node_uuid.log``. How ipmitool driver saves the console log is yet tbd. It can use third party tools such as ``conserver``which can connect to console and keep the log via the configuration in ``conserver.cf``. The ipminative driver will use the third party python library ``confluent`` to save the console log. ``confluent`` has interactive console support to access console interactively from either the web browser or the command line interface. So it can be used to replace the shellinabox web console for ipminative driver. * Driver interface change for console log The following new functions will be added to the ``ironic.driver.base.ConsoleInterface``. - ``get_console_output()`` - retrieves the last MAX_CONSOLE_BYTES of console log for the node. MAX_CONSOLE_BYTES equals 100 * units.Ki. - ``start_console_server()`` - start the console log server method. - ``stop_console_server()`` - stop the console log server method. - ``clean_console_log()`` - delete the console log file. The following functions will be modified in the ``ironic.driver.base.ConsoleInterface``. - ``start_console`` - will connect to the third party console server such as ``conserver`` or ``confluent`` when the ``console_log_mode`` value is ``all`` or ``on_enabled``. - ``stop_console`` - if ``console_log_mode`` is set to ``on_enabled``, stop console log for the node after console disconnecting from console server. The ipmitool and ipminative drivers will implement above interfaces. * Conductor manager change for console log - start saving the console log when node deploy is requested. - delete the old console log contents for the specific node when node clean is requested. - stop console server for the specific node when node destroy is requested. * A REST API ``GET v1/nodes/<uuid>/states/console_output`` will be added. It takes the length as the parameter that is the number of lines from the latest console output. * The Ironic Nova virt driver will call this new REST API for console log support for bare metal nodes. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- The following new REST API will be added for node: :: GET /v1/nodes/<uuid>/states/console_output Parameters: length(int) -- the number of line of console output from the latest console log. RPC API impact -------------- * A new RPC method will be added to RPC API: get_console_output(<node id>, <tail length>) which will return the content of the latest console log with the given length. Driver API impact ----------------- Other drivers can optionally implement the newly added functions from ``ironic.driver.base.ConsoleInterface``. Nova driver impact ------------------ The ``get_console_output`` function in Ironic Nova virt driver will call the REST API ``/v1/nodes/<uuid>/states/console_output`` of ``ironic.api.controllers.v1.NodeConsoleController`` from ironicclient Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- The ironic nova driver will call the ``get_console_output`` function to retrieve the console output. Hence the ``nova console-log`` command which calls Nova driver for console log will be connected to this function , and so does Horizon. These are good impacts for end users. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ Saving the console output to a log file for a bare metal nodes requires persistent session connection and constant console saving from BMC to the ironic-conductor host. This may consume more network flow in the hardware management network when a large number of nodes are being deployed at the same time. The admin has to consider this factor when turning ``console_log_mode`` to ``all``. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: chenglch <chenglch@cn.ibm.com> Other contributors: baiyuan <bybai@cn.ibm.com> linggao <linggao@us.ibm.com> Jarrod Johnson <jjohnson2@lenovo.com> in ``confluent`` Work Items ---------- * Add new configuration options. * Add new common functions in the driver.base.ConsoleInterface. * Add REST API for console output. * Implement console saving in ipmitool driver using ``conserver``. * Implement console saving using ``confluent`` in ipminative driver. * Implement console log retrieving and cleaning in ipmitool driver. * Implement console log retrieving cleaning in ipminative driver. * Implement console log saving, retrieving and cleaning in conductor manager. * Implement the Nova side of this feature. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= * Need real IPMI hardware. * Need test with nova: This will involve installing OpenStack with Nova Ironic Driver. The command to get the console log is: :: nova console-log <server> [--length <length>] * Need test with Horizon. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== The new console log functions in both the REST API and the driver API will need to be documented. References ========== [0] - Confluent console demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8NEgyH_4gfo (Confluent does not have documents). [1] - Conserver: http://www.conserver.com/

commit_message:
Add Solaris IPMItool driver

This design spec introduces support for deploying Oracle hardware with Oracle
Solaris using IPMItool and Automated Installer interfaces.

Change-Id: I26955b47a0cd3dfe6d2063a5e41ec9cfb32ae0a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/36/231536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Solaris IPMITool ironic driver ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/solaris-ipmitool-driver This blueprint proposes adding a new driver to support the deployment of Oracle Solaris on Oracle servers. Problem description =================== Ironic currently lacks support for deploying Oracle Solaris on Oracle servers. This blueprint proposes to extend Ironic providing a new Oracle Solaris specific driver which utilizes Oracle Solaris deployment technology and IPMI to provision Oracle Solaris bare metal instances. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes to implement a new driver `solaris_ipmitool` that will utilize IPMITool to communicate with Oracle Hardware's Integrated Lights Out Manager (ILOM) for power management and setting boot device. Actual deployment of Solaris will be achieved using the Automated Installer(AI)[2]. The following interfaces will be defined: * Add new driver file `ironic/drivers/solaris.py` which will define driver class SolarisAndIPMIToolDriver inherited from base.BaseDriver. Specific interfaces within this driver will be defined as follows: * self.power = ipmitool.IPMIPower() * self.deploy = solaris_ipmitool.SolarisDeploy() * self.management = solaris_ipmitool.SolarisManagement() * self.inspect = solaris_ipmitool.SolarisInspect() * self.console = None * self.rescue = None * self.vendor = None | * Add new module `ironic/drivers/solaris_ipmitool.py` which will define the following classes: * class `SolarisDeploy()` inherited from `base.DeployInterface`. Perform actual node deployment specifically using the Automated Installer. Following methods will be provided : * `get_properties()` - retrieve driver properties. * `validate()` - Validate node for solaris_ipmitool driver. * `deploy()` - Actual node deployment, set boot device, power cylce etc. * `tear_down()` - Decommission node, power down etc. * `prepare()` - Prepare node and AI Server for deployment. * `clean_up()` - Clean up node and AI Server configuration. | * class `SolarisManagement()` inherited from `base.ManagementInterface`. Following methods will be provided : * `get_properties()` - retrieve driver properties. * `validate()` - Validate nodes driver_info * `get_supported_boot_devices()` - Return a list of supported boot devices specific to this node. * `set_boot_device()` - Set nodes boot device. * `get_boot_device()` - Get current nodes boot device. * `get_sensors_data()` - Retrive node sensor data. | * class `SolarisInspect()` inherited from `base.InspectInterface`. Following methods will be provided : * `get_properties()` - retrieve driver properties. * `validate()` - Validate nodes driver_info. * `inspect_hardware()` - Perform hardware inspection of specific node. | * class `AIService()`. Utility class used for interacting with an AI service. * class `DeployStateChecker()` inherited from `Thread`. Class to periodically check the state of a currently running deployment. The Ironic node will be updated appropriately depending on current state of deployment and the Thread is exited when the deployment has finished either successfully or not. Alternatives ------------ No other alternatives are available, as current driver set within Ironic does not support deployment of Oracle Solaris. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The following driver_info fields are required when enrolling a node in ironic: * `ipmi_address`: Hostname/ip-address of node's ILOM * `ipmi_username`: ILOM User account to connect via IPMI * `ipmi_password`: ILOM User account password The following optional `driver_info` fields can be added when enrolling a node. Which ones are added depends on how the node is to be deployed. * `ai_manifest`: Automated install manifest to be used for provisioning. * `ai_service`: Name of Automated Install service to use. * `archive_uri`: URI of unified archive(UAR) to deploy. * `fmri`: List of IPS package FMRIs to be installed. Required if publishers property is set. * `install_profiles`: List of AI configuration profiles to be applied to the installation environment during an install. * `publishers`: List of IPS publishers to install from. Required if fmri property is set. * `sc_profiles`: List of AI system configuration profiles to be applied to an installed system. Create two new ironic sections in ironic configuration file /etc/ironic/ironic.conf. New `[ai]` section which will contain the following paramaters : * `server`: Hostname/ip-address of AI Server. Default is None. Required. * `username`: Username to administer AI Server with over SSH. Default is None. Required. * `password`: Password for AI administration user. Default is None. * `ssh_key_file`: File containing SSH Key. Default is None. * `ssh_key_contents`: SSH key contents to use. Default is None. One of password, ssh_key_file or ssh_key_contents is required. * `port`: SSH port to use. * `timeout`: SSH socket timeout value in seconds. Default is 10. * `deploy_interval`: Interval in seconds to check AI deployment status. Default is 10. * `derived_manifest`: Location of default AI Derived Manifest to use. Default is file:///usr/lib/ironic/ironic-manifest.ksh. New `[solaris_ipmi]` section which will contain the following paramaters : * `imagecache_dirname`: Default path to image cache. Default is /var/lib/ironic/images', * `imagecache_lock_timeout`: Timeout in seconds to wait when attempting to lock image cached reference count file. Default is 60 seconds. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: MattMan Work Items ---------- * Implement new `solaris_ipmitool` driver. * Implement unit-test cases for `solaris_ipmitool` driver. * Write configuration documentation. Dependencies ============ This driver requires the Solaris Operating System and Oracle Solaris Hardware running Oracle's Integrated Lights Out Manager(ILOM). Testing ======= Unit-tests will be implemented for the new `solaris_ipmitool` driver. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== This driver will not break any compatibility with either of REST API or RPC APIs. Documentation Impact ==================== * Write configuration documentation. * Update Ironic documentation section _`Enabling Drivers`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/drivers.html with Solaris driver related instructions. References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197554/ [2] http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E36784_01/html/E36800/useaipart.html#scrolltoc
